text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with paper pork that's right i'm
very excited to show you this new method
I've been using for roasting pork
shoulder and while the results have been
getting are very impressive there is one
small problem I'm not actually sure if
the paper I'm using in this technique is
doing anything or not I mean I think it
is and it seems like it is and it feels
like it is but to be completely honest
if it is I'm not sure exactly why
although I do have a theory which I will
share later but for now let's just go
ahead and get started and we will begin
with a very simple dry rub so - a
generous amount of kosher salt we will
add some freshly ground black pepper
as well as some smoked paprika and then
we'll also add some garlic powder and
onion powder
no not onion salt and garlic salt that
is just pure granulated onion garlic and
then we'll finish up with a nice big
spoon of cayenne for some heat which we
will then balance with some brown sugar
for some sweet and that is going to be
it for our dry rub so we will give that
a mix and once that's that we can move
on and apply it to our pork shoulder and
there it is we have a seven pound a
bone-in pork shoulder also known as pork
but it's a long story
and yes that bone you can see on the
side there is the shoulder blade and
what we need to do here is coat that
meat thoroughly and evenly including of
course any nooks and crannies and this
is probably a great time to mention this
is not a recipe it's actually a
techniques video so even though I showed
you the dry rub I'm going to use this
really will work with any one you want
you are the eric holder of your pork
shoulder so it's going to be up to you
to decide which spice rub will do this
justice but anyway no matter what you
end up using we will apply that rub to
our meat and then once that's been
accomplished we can move on to the
wrapping and paper part of the program
and not just any paper we're going to
need some parchment paper which is what
I have right here and what we'll want to
do is cut off a nice long piece probably
four feet or more and we will place our
pork down and basically just roll it up
and we're actually going to do two
layers of paper and it's not going to
matter as much for the second piece but
for this first wrapping try to get it
nice and tight okay we want this paper
pressed up nice and tight against that
meat so we'll go ahead and roll in wrap
our pork in that first piece of paper
and then like I said we're gonna
that again in a second piece so we'll
place our pork down turn this way and
we'll wrap that up and because parchment
paper is kind of slippery it's gonna be
tougher to get this one really tight but
don't worry about it because we're gonna
encase this all in foil so just wrap it
up as tightly and neatly as you can oh
by the way when you're shopping for your
parchment paper what you're looking for
is something that's all natural and not
bleached so yes they do sell white
colored parchment paper that's been
bleached first but I'm not sure why
you'd want to introduce something that's
been bleached when you don't have to and
besides this stuff looks like butcher
paper which I feel at the end is gonna
give us a more authentic and meaty
presentation and then once we're setting
this in foil and just like the first
piece of parchment paper try to wrap
this first layer foil as tight as you
can okay so make sure you given it the
old tuck and squeeze as you go and once
we have that wrapped in that first piece
of foil as shown we will wrap it up in a
second piece but we will lay our pork
the other direction and by the way I do
recommend using heavy duty foil for this
I'm not sure exactly when they started
making regular foil so thin but you can
tear that stuff just by looking at it
wrong so I do generally use heavy duty
for pretty much everything and then to
finish this off we will wrap it in a
third piece of foil and yes
unfortunately there's more wrapping
footage than there is things to talk
about so I apologize I don't have any
more interesting filler I guess I could
try joke so this horse walks into a bar
and the bartender looks at him and says
hey why the long face I guess we could
have just had silence but anyway we will
mercifully finish up the wrapping and
we'll go ahead and transfer that into
some kind of roasting pan and by the way
no matter how you place this in here a
little bit of fat and/or juice is gonna
leak out but have you said that I do
like to have any seams on the top or at
least facing up and at that point where
we're calling paper pork is ready for
the oven so what we'll do is transfer
this into the center of a 225 degree
oven for exactly 1 in 3/4 hours per
pound which for me ended up being a
total of 12 and a half hours so I'll
generally start this late at night so
it's ready to the next afternoon and
after roasting in that nice slow oven
for about 12 and a half hours this is
what mine look like and as you can see
we did have a little bit of leakage but
barely enough to mention and then what
we want to do as soon as that comes out
is nothing for at least
our don't do anything just let it sit
there yes if you have a wicked case of
the munchies you can unwrap this and eat
it immediately but I think if you let it
sit those juices are gonna redistribute
and I think it'll be a little nicer it
should still be pretty hot so I did that
mind set for about an hour before
painstakingly unwrapping and please be
careful if you're doing this hot there's
definitely gonna be some fat and juices
between those layers oh and by the way
when I mentioned in the beginning that I
wasn't sure exactly why this worked but
I had a theory what I think might be
happening here is that paper kind of
forms a membrane which sorta insulates
the pork because paper is not a very
good conductor of heat and I blew that
provides a very nice moist gentle
cooking environment in fact the earliest
form of barbecue is actually meat
covered in wet leaves set over a fire so
who knows maybe we're actually
simulating that or not all I know is
this comes out amazingly moist and very
very succulent and please note even
though we cooked this for 12 and a half
hours it has not collapsed down into a
pile of dry overcooked meat
it actually looks more like a pork roast
but check this out here's how you can
usually tell you're dealing with a
perfectly cooked pork shoulder if we can
pull that shoulder blade bone out like
this and it comes out easily and clean
and glistening with moisture that is
perfect so that's what we're gonna shoot
for and since I've already broken this
open I might as well grab a fork and go
in for a taste which really was
extraordinary just wonderfully moist and
soft and tender without being mushy and
as you'll notice the nice thing about
pork shoulders you can actually eat a
little bit and put it back together and
your guests will never know and then as
far as presentation goes for this what I
like to do is transfer into some kind of
serving platter with the paper which I
think not only makes for a provocative
and very enticing presentation but it's
also gonna trap in and hold those
natural cooking juices which we can
brush over to make everything look nice
and moist and shiny and obviously if
you're gonna use this stuff for pulled
pork sandwiches which you really should
you will of course mix most if not all
those juices back in but anyway we'll
brush a little look at you over the top
and then finish up with a little bit of
green onion for the pictures and that's
it our paper pork is done and ready to
enjoy in so many delicious ways and I'll
be finishing up this video by showing
you my favorite which is simply just
broken up or cut up or shredded up
and piled up on a roll with your
favorite barbecue sauce and if you
notice I do break it or cut it up into
smaller pieces but I don't like to shred
it or mash it down to a paste I do
prefer some identifiable pieces of meat
involved so we'll go ahead and pile that
up on a definitely not homemade roll and
finish up with a little bit of barbecue
sauce I know it doesn't look like
barbecue sauce but it is that's a little
something I call see-through barbecue
sauce which is my take on a North
Carolina hot pepper vinegar style sauce
which many people are saying on my demo
next week so stay tuned for that whoops
lost little piece don't worry I'll leave
that little piece when I change the
camera angle there we go but anyway
that's it paper pork whether you're
going to use it in the sandwich like
this we're simply on a plate with some
fabulous fixings I really do hope you
give this incredible technique a try
soon so head over to food whooshes calm
for all the ingredients have more info
as usual and as always enjoy
you
